''[[Other People (film)|Other People]]'' }} '''Chris Kelly''' (born September 7, 1983) is an [[Americans|American]] writer and director known for his work on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', and writing and directing the autobiographical film ''[[Other People (film)|Other People]]'' that premiered at the [[2016 Sundance Film Festival]]. He has received five Emmy nominations for his work on ''SNL''. ==Career== ===Early career=== Kelly grew up in [[Sacramento, California]], the son of Joanne ''née'' Kellogg (1960–2009) Kelly. He has a sister, Janelle, and a half sister, Katie, from his mother's re-marriage.[http://www.egcitizen.com/obituaries/joanne-piazza/article_a4a78f99-833f-5e53-adaf-15b5e0769a55.html Joanne Kelly Obituary] accessed 11/23/2016{{cite web|title=I Think I Have Overstayed My Welcome In Sacramento|url=http://chriskelly.tumblr.com/post/221604888/i-think-i-have-overstayed-my-welcome-in-sacramento|website=tumblr.com|accessdate=28 January 2016}} He attended college at [[UC Irvine]].{{cite news|last1=Dang|first1=Mike|title=Inside the Thriving Comedy Career of ‘SNL’ and ‘Broad City’ Writer Chris Kelly|url=https://thebillfold.com/inside-the-thriving-comedy-career-of-snl-and-broad-city-writer-chris-kelly-78e1fcda8d02#.x9niruhsh|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=The Billfold|date=8 March 2016}} He was a staff writer and director at [[Funny or Die]] and ''[[Onion News Network]]'', the latter of which won the 2009 [[Peabody Award]]. He was also Head Writer for Matt Besser's Comedy Central special ''This Show Will Get You High'' in 2010. Kelly also performed at [[Upright Citizens Brigade|UCBNY]] with his storytelling show ''Chris Kelly: America's Princess Diana'', and before that, wrote, directed and starred in the play, ''Oh My God, I Heard You're Dying!'' He was on various Maude Teams as both a writer and actor, including ''Stone Cold Fox'', ''27 Kidneys'', and ''Thunder Gulch'', and was a frequent monologist at [[ASSSSCAT]] in both NYC and LA.{{cite web|title=Chris Kelly|url=http://ucbcomedy.com/user/5923|website=ucbcomedy.com|accessdate=27 January 2016}} ===''Saturday Night Live''=== Currently, Kelly is a [[List of Saturday Night Live writers|supervising writer]] for ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' having joined the show as a staff writer for the [[Saturday Night Live (season 37)|37th season]] and promoted to supervising writer on the [[Saturday Night Live (season 40)|40th season]]. Along with his SNL writing partner, [[Sarah Schneider]], Kelly has created many sketches including: "(Do It On My) Twin Bed," "Back Home Ballers," "The Beygency" (about [[Beyoncé]]), and "First Got Horny 2 U."{{cite news|last1=Steiner|first1=Amanda Michelle|title=Sarah Schneider & Chris Kelly talk 'First Got Horny 2 U,' the ladies of SNL, Beyoncé, and more|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/11/20/snl-writers-chris-kelly-sarah-schneider-interview|accessdate=28 January 2016|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|date=November 20, 2015}} He and Schneider primarily write for [[Aidy Bryant]] and [[Kate McKinnon]], including "Dyke and Fats."{{cite web|title=‘SNL’s’ Sarah Schneider & Chris Kelly Reminisce About Writing ‘Back Home Ballers’ Sketch|url=http://aboveaverage.com/snls-sarah-schneider-chris-kelly-reminisce-about-writing-back-home-ballers-sketch/|website=aboveaverage.com|accessdate=28 January 2016}} Kelly has been nominated for five [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s for his work on ''SNL''. In August 2016, it was announced that Kelly and Schneider would be co-head writers for SNL's [[Saturday Night Live (season 42)|42nd season]].{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Nate|title=Chris Kelly and Sarah Schneider Are Your Newest SNL Head Writers|url=http://www.vulture.com/2016/08/chris-kelly-schneider-are-newest-snl-head-writers.html|accessdate=13 August 2016|work=Vulture|publisher=''[[New York Magazine]]''|date=August 12, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Megh|title=‘SNL’ Promotes Sarah Schneider and Chris Kelly to Co-Head Writers|url=http://splitsider.com/2016/08/snl-promotes-sarah-schneider-and-chris-kelly-to-co-head-writers/|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=[[Splitsider]]|date=12 August 2016}} Kelly is the first openly gay head writer of SNL.{{cite news|last1=Reynolds|first1=Daniel|title=Chris Kelly Makes SNL History as First Out Head Writer|url=http://www.advocate.com/television/2016/8/16/chris-kelly-makes-snl-history-first-out-head-writer|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=[[The Advocate]]|date=16 August 2016}} ===''Broad City''=== Kelly is also a writer and consulting producer on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Broad City]]'', which earned him a nomination for the [[Writers Guild of America Award for Television: Comedy Series]]. He was a self described fan of the ''Broad City'' web series and joined the show as a writer and consulting producer when it was picked up as a series on Comedy Central.{{cite news|last1=Blake|first1=Meredith|title='Broad City' brings female misadventures to male-oriented Comedy Central|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2014/jan/17/entertainment/la-et-st-broad-city-comedy-central-20140119/2|accessdate=28 January 2016|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=January 17, 2014}} ===Film=== Kelly wrote and directed his first feature film, [[Other People (film)|''Other People'']], that premiered at the [[2016 Sundance Film Festival]] in the opening slot.{{cite web|last1=Jeff Sneider And Matt Donnelly|title=Sundance 2016: 13 Hot Directors to Watch|url=http://www.thewrap.com/sundance-2016-13-hot-directors-to-watch/|website=TheWrap|accessdate=27 January 2016|language=en-US}} The film is about a struggling comedy writer (played by [[Jesse Plemons]]), who has just broken up with his boyfriend and moves from New York City to Sacramento to help his sick mother (played by [[Molly Shannon]]).{{cite news|last1=Yohannes|first1=Alamin|title='SNL' Writer Chris Kelly Taps Into His Life Story for 'Other People'|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/chris-kelly-taps-his-story-directorial-debut-other-people-n621696|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=NBC News|date=August 3, 2016}} He has to live with his conservative father and younger sisters for the first time in many years and feels like a stranger in his childhood home. As his mother’s health deteriorates, David tries to extract meaning from the awful experience and convince everyone that he's doing okay.{{cite web|title=Other People|url=http://www.sundance.org/projects/other-people|website=www.sundance.org|accessdate=27 January 2016}} The film is loosely based on his own life drawing from his experience of losing his mother to cancer in 2009.{{cite news|last1=Dowd|first1=A.A.|title=Sundance begins with a divisive "Sundance movie," go figure|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/sundance-begins-divisive-sundance-movie-go-figure-231133|accessdate=27 January 2016|work=www.avclub.com|date=January 22, 2016}} He was labeled one of the "13 Hot Directors to Watch" at Sundance in 2016. ==Personal life== Kelly currently lives in [[Los Angeles]] with his boyfriend and their dog Harry.{{cite web|title=Purebred Breeders Sold Me A Sick Puppy Who Almost Died And Might Still Die|url=http://chriskelly.tumblr.com/post/97822779697/purebred-breeders-sold-me-a-sick-puppy-who-almost|website=chriskelly.tumblr.com|accessdate=27 January 2016}} ==Awards and nominations== Kelly received the following awards and nominations: ===Peabody Award=== *[[List of Peabody Award winners (2000–09)|2009 Peabody Award]] -
